definition: Group 2 metallic elements with two valence electrons that form divalent cations and basic oxides

positive_examples: The calcium in milk helps strengthen bones and teeth.
Magnesium supplements can help reduce muscle cramps after exercise.
Barium sulfate is used as a contrast agent in medical X-rays.
The brilliant white flame indicates the presence of magnesium in the firework.
Strontium gives red fireworks their distinctive crimson color.
Radium was once used to make glow-in-the-dark watch dials before its dangers were known.
negative_examples: Sodium chloride dissolves easily in water to form table salt.
The aluminum foil wrapped around the leftover pizza.
Iron oxide causes the reddish-brown rust on old cars.
Copper pipes are commonly used in residential plumbing systems.
The gold necklace gleamed in the jewelry store window.
Carbon dioxide emissions contribute to climate change.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: AlkaliMetals, TransitionMetals, NobleGases, Halogens

opposite_reasoning: Halogen provides the strongest opposition for Fisher-LDA purposes. The electron-donating vs electron-accepting behavior creates maximal chemical contrast along a meaningful axis. While AI safety steering utility is moderate (this is domain-specific chemistry), the opposition strength is excellent for creating a clear concept axis. Halogens and alkaline earth metals represent opposite extremes of periodic table reactivity and bonding behavior.
